conversation.content: [confused] Mrs. Henderson? I knocked several times but the door was already open, and I noticed all these boxes in the hallway— [pause] Is everything alright with your mother?
[exhausted] She's upstairs, probably pretending to sleep like she does every morning when she hears someone coming. [bitter] Twelve years I've been doing this dance with her, but not anymore.
[hesitantly] I don't understand, are you moving? [quietly] Your mother never mentioned anything about relocating, and she usually tells me everything during our sessions.

[firmly] My mother tells people what she wants them to hear. [sighs] Did she mention the three times she left the stove on last month, or how she accused me of stealing her jewelry that she'd hidden in the freezer?
[very quietly] No, she didn't.

[speaking fast] Of course she didn't, because then you'd have to report it, and then social services would get involved, and God forbid anyone think she's not perfectly capable of living independently.
Mrs. Henderson, I've been caring for your mother for two years now, and while she has her moments, I've never seen anything that would suggest— [pause] Are you sure this is the right decision?
[loudly] Right decision? [laugh] I haven't had a full night's sleep since 2012, haven't been on a date in five years, and my entire savings is gone from paying for her care.
[empathetically] I understand this must be incredibly difficult for you, but moving her into a facility might not be what she needs right now. [gently] She's comfortable here, she knows this house.
[bitter] This house is killing both of us. [very quietly] I found her wandering the neighborhood at three in the morning last week looking for my father—he's been dead for fifteen years.
[shocked] She was wandering? [concerned] Mrs. Henderson, that's a serious safety issue, why didn't you call me or the agency?
[defeated] Because then it becomes real, doesn't it? [sighs] Once you put it in a report, once it's documented, you can't pretend anymore that everything's going to magically get better.
Your mother loves you more than anything in this world, she talks about you constantly during our time together. [softly] She's going to feel so abandoned.
[angrily] Abandoned? [laughs bitterly] I gave up my career, my marriage, my entire life to take care of her, and she doesn't even remember my name half the time.
[firmly] Memory loss doesn't erase love, Mrs. Henderson. [pause] Even if she can't express it the way she used to, somewhere deep inside, she knows you're her daughter.
[crying while speaking] That's exactly why I can't do this anymore—watching her disappear piece by piece while I disappear right alongside her. [shaky voice] I need to exist again, I need to breathe.
[very quietly] When are you planning to move her? [sighs] I should probably say goodbye properly, she's going to notice if I just stop coming.
[whispering] Tomorrow morning.
[slowly] Tomorrow? [upset] That's so soon, she won't have time to process this, to understand what's happening—you can't just rip her away from everything she knows without warning.
[firmly] I can. [pause] I am.

scenario: A home health aide arrives for their regular shift to find their elderly patient's daughter packing up the house, having finally decided to place her mother in a care facility after years of caregiving.
